awd_titl_txt: EAGER: SUPER: Carbon-based Superconductors Stable at Ambient Temperature and Pressure
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The existence of superconductors - materials that conduct electricity without resistance - at conditions of the Earth’s surface would revolutionize diverse technologies ranging from the electrical grid to computing and communications. New materials displaying superconductivity at or near room temperature have been discovered but they are stable only at very high pressures, such as found within the core of the Earth. The paramount challenge, both fundamentally and for eventual applications, is stabilizing these and related superconducting materials at ambient pressure. This project, supported by the Division of Materials Research at NSF, addresses this challenge through integrated theoretical calculations and experiments to examine previously unexplored chemical compositions, with a focus on carbon-rich materials. The guiding hypothesis is that structures in which carbon has the bonding properties of diamond could lead to room-temperature superconductivity at ambient pressure. Carbon-rich compounds are systematically explored using synthesis at high pressures and temperature in combination with both simultaneous characterization and sophisticated computations to interpret and guide the experiments. The project involves education and training of undergraduate students from the diverse population of the University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC). The success of this research would lead to important advances in basic science, create potential for major shifts in technology, and train the next generation of scientists, including groups underrepresented in STEM fields.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The quest for materials that exhibit superconducting critical temperatures near ambient conditions has been a long-sought goal of condensed matter physics, which among others, could be key to quantum information technology. Guided by increasingly accurate predictions of targeted chemical compositions using density functional theory, high-pressure experiments have demonstrated the existence of superconductivity at record high temperature in hydrogen-rich materials. Replacement of hydrogen with carbon in some of these materials is predicted to give rise to high critical temperature in structures that can be preserved on decompression, owing to their rigid carbon frameworks, which impart kinetic stabilization at ambient conditions, much like for diamond. This project, supported by the Division of Materials Research, will involve an interdisciplinary team at UIC to carry out an accelerated exploration of carbon-rich phases, beginning with light alkali metal-containing materials, using in situ x-ray diffraction with heating and pressurization, measurements of superconductivity, and tests of kinetic stability at or near ambient pressure. The experiments are integrated with and informed by DFT and other theoretical calculations, augmented by machine learning approaches and other large data techniques. The UIC group incorporates the approaches developed in the project in university courses. Undergraduates from the diverse student population of UIC, a minority serving institution, take part in this research and education experience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Funded by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program at the National Science Foundation, researchers at the University of Illinois Chicago investigated the behavior of carbon materials combined with alkali metals (lithium, potassium, and sodium) under high pressure, with the goal to discover new materials which could display structural features associated with potential superconducting properties. The project combined experimental and computational approaches.

The team implemented a novel path to synthesize lithium-carbon compounds through electrochemical methods, where lithium atoms insert between graphite layers to form ordered structures known as graphite intercalation compounds. These high-quality samples served as the foundation for high-pressure experiments. Using diamond anvil cells, they subjected these materials to extreme pressures (up to 60 GPa, equivalent to about 600,000 atmospheres) and temperatures (up to 1000K or 1340°F). As pressure increased, structural transformations were observed in the most saturated lithium-carbon compound, with one lithium for every 6 carbon atoms. Armed with this tool, they established precise measurements of how these materials compress under pressure (their equation of state) up to 60 GPa, providing valuable data for theoretical models.

The team subsequently expanded their investigation of graphite intercalation compounds to include sodium-carbon and potassium-carbon systems. In the compound with a potassium-carbon ratio of 1 to 8, in situ experiments documented significant phase transitions at 2.3 GPa and 10 GPa, with the latter producing a new tetragonal phase stable at pressures up to 50 GPa. In the case sodium-carbon compounds, no graphite intercalation compounds are known at ambient conditions, but the team successfully stabilized structures with sodium-carbon ratios as high as 1 to 4 under pressure. These sodium-carbon materials provide new insight into materials that could be of interest in sodium-ion batteries (potential alternatives to lithium-ion batteries) aside from possibly exhibiting superconductivity at temperatures at high temperature.

In parallel to experimental efforts, the team developed sophisticated machine learning frameworks to accelerate materials discovery, combining Random Forest algorithms with data from established materials databases. These models identified promising compositional regions for high-temperature superconductivity and predicted several compositions with potential superconducting properties. An innovative Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) approach—a system where two artificial intelligence programs compete to generate and evaluate new materials—enhanced the potential to discover promising compounds. This computational framework demonstrated the ability to predict superconducting temperatures for materials not included in its training data, validating its effectiveness for exploring new compositional spaces much faster than traditional experimental methods.

This project supported the training of three graduate students, providing them with expertise in the cutting-edge experimental techniques (diamond anvil cells, synchrotron X-ray diffraction) and computational methods (machine learning, density functional theory). One student participated in the National School on Neutron and X-ray Scattering and gained valuable experience at major research facilities including Argonne National Laboratory and the German Electron Synchrotron.

The computational methods developed during this project have been integrated into graduate coursework on computational materials design, benefiting science and engineering students. The findings have been presented at American Chemical Society and American Physical Society meetings, contributing to the broader scientific community's knowledge.

The discovery of new structures and phase transitions in these compounds advances fundamental materials science while offering potential applications in efficient electrical transmission, supporting national priorities in advanced materials and energy technologies.


Last Modified: 03/10/2025
Modified by: Jordi Cabana
